Name: Mrs. Rosamond J. Hanson
Address: Box 317, Wapella, Sask.
Birthplace: Chulmleigh, Devon, England

1. INDUSTRY: HOUSEHOLD
   - What year did you start housekeeping in eastern Canada? Nov. 1903.
   - Where did you set up housekeeping? Same farm at Wapella.
   - Where had you been living before that? Devon, England.
   - For how many people did you prepare meals? Three usually, at first.
   - How far was it to your nearest store? 2-3 miles.
   - How often could a visit be made to the store? Twice a week.
   - What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years?
     Only necessaries: sugar, tea, cocoa, coffee, vinegar, syrup, rolled oats, flour, canned salmon, soda biscuits, cheese, spices, mustard, jelly powders.

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS
   - What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Lake of the Woods, Harvest Queen or Fine Roses.
   - In what quantities did you buy it? 100 lbs.
   - What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $2.50.
   - How much did you use graham flour? Not much.
   - Whole wheat flour? Own ground.
   - Was flour milled locally? Yes, for a time until moved away.
   - What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? 65 cents.
   - What other grain products did you use?
     Cornmeal? No.
     Whole wheat? Yes.
     Other? None.
   - Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? Yes.
   - How did you grind it? With an own feed grinder.
1. How did you start working in the early 1900s?
   - There was no housework.
   - I worked at a factory.
   - I lived in England.

2. How many people did you support?
   - 3-5 people.

3. How often could you visit the store?
   - Twice a week.

4. What essentials did you usually buy in those earliest years?
   - Sugar, tea, coffee, onions, sugar, rolled oats, flour, canned salmon, soda crackers, cheese, apples, mustard, jelly, pickles.

5. What other products did you use?
   - Cornmeal, flour, sugar, salt, butter, eggs.

6. Did you grind your own flour for pancakes?
   - Yes.

7. How did you make bread?
   - By hand.

Did you make your own vinegar? No

Our President father sold 8 loads of potatoes for 25¢/lb
Hauling them over 25 miles, the 8th load found the market glutted, so were given to a widow who made a living. Worth boarders & one of earliest settlers in the Wapella district

Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

Water is now pumped into the barn for the cattle milk cows to drink out of water bowls. For the weekly wash, we have a large cement cistern in the cellar, & a pump in the kitchen, since 1930.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

Breakfast:
- Oatmeal Porridge - egg, if possible; hot biscuit; dried fruit; tea, brown or white bread and butter (no margarine); milk

Dinner:
- Boiled beef stew with vegetables, onion, bread, butter
- Mashed or baked potatoes, rice pudding or pie
- Supper:
  - Cold meat or canned fish
  - Fried potatoes
  - Dried fruit
  - Cooked tea with milk and sugar

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Western Canada? _________________. Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at that time.

Baked chicken & vegetables, plum pudding, mince pie, jelly with whipped cream, mixed fruit cake, cookies.

Present: Husband, baby daughter (3 months), hired man, two bachelor neighbors, generally one or two unmarried men.

19. Have you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

Had extremely difficult period, the 1907 frost destroyed most of the crops, credit was stopped and groceries were scarce. However, a mink in Henhouse was shot, & the skin bought one mixed cake, groceries we shall always remember. Our first experience with frozen wheat in 1907, the mink killed but I knew better a well directed 22. got the mink, it was a good dark skin & never before or since have we seen mink on our farm. Also muskrat has been plentiful when the sloughs are full of water.
many methods today and cellulose haukens.

1. I read a simple day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year. It was a white bread and butter (no margarine) filled oatmeal porridge. Egg, toast, hot water, rice pudding, fruit.

2. That year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in eastern Canada?

3. Baked chicken & vegetables. Plum pudding, mince pie, jelly with whipped cream. Under fruit cake, apple pie.

4. Parent's husband, half daughter, monthly board, generally men two or more ten bachelor neighbors, generally men two or more unmarried men.

5. How you ever returned to almost starvation.

6. Locally produced foods. Give details.

7. Had extremely difficult period, the 1907/8.

8. Destroyed most of the crops, wheat was obtained and grown in new season, however, a mild winter was short, the skin brought our flour cake premium we shall always remember our first experiment with frozen wheat in 1907, the result hardly worth it then, a well divided 29. got the minute, it was a poor dark skin, a new degree on since have we seen minute flour on our farm, also wheat has been plentiful when the sloughs are full of water.
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

Some farms are equipped with hydro + electricity from wind power. 32 Volts has lighted our homes & barns instead of the coal oil sold at 35cts a gallon. Cake mixes, and cornflakes are in common use also prepared salad dressing, white & brown baked bread and also cookies + cakes. Less work if one is unable to do the work of baking.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homemad and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

Since 1918. War end brought many changes.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. Use back of page if more space is needed.

The rule of many farms near Wapella was to run a yearly store bill, which was paid as soon as threshing was finished. Today the farm women receive cash for nearly everything they sell, and they pay cash for the family groceries, which is much the nicest way.

Fifty years has improved farm conditions for women in the prairie section. Many immigrants today have no idea of the conditions which pioneers improved. The women pioneers are the unsung heroines of Western Canada. May their memory never fade as they are an example of thrift and Endurance and honesty.
Some farms are equipped with hydro or electricity.

From wood stove, coal oil sold at $3.50 a gallon.
